title: Sessions: 'Future Needs' Of Prison System Will Require Private Prisons
text:
Another Obama-era plan has been reversed.
Focusing on the “future needs” of the federal prison system, Attorney General Jeff Sessions on Thursday countermanded an order issued last year that sought to phase out the use of private prisons .
Last August , then-Deputy Attorney General Sally Yates told Bureau of Prisons officials to either terminate or vastly reduce any contracts with the operators of private prisons.

Bush’s Sessions said that order “changed the long-standing policy and practice, and impaired the Bureau’s ability to meet the future needs of the federal correctional system.”
“Therefore, I direct the Bureau to return to its previous approach,” he wrote.
A Justice Department spokesperson said the memo from Sessions will “restore BOP’s flexibility to manage the federal prison inmate population based on capacity needs.”

There are currently 12 private prisons in operation that house about 21,000 federal inmates.
Three corporations operate private prisons — Corrections Corporation of America, GEO Group, and Management and Training Corporation. Collectively, they received $639 million from the government in fiscal year 2014.
The American Civil Liberties Union objected to the change.

Fathi, director of the ACLU’s National Prison Project.
“The memo from Attorney General Sessions ignores this fact. Additionally, this memo is a further sign that under President Trump and Attorney General Sessions, the United States may be headed for a new federal prison boom, fueled in part by criminal prosecutions of immigrants for entering the country.”
Bloomberg reported that most inmates held at private facilities used by the Justice Department are sentenced “criminal aliens,” according to the Bureau of Prisons.
That group would include illegal immigrants convicted of drug offenses.
